attributes.action: Require plastic food containers to contain a minimum percentage recycled plastic
attributes.additional_details: This will aid in reducing fossil fuel usage and contribute towards green energy commitments. It is consistent with government policy and prior  initiatives to encourage business uptake through legislation
attributes.background: Houses need to have a minimum of insulation. Petrol must contain a minimum of ethanol. We should introduce a minimum requirement that plastic food containers manufactured or sold in the UK (bottles, food packaging, etc) contain a minimum percentage of recycled plastic and to increase this over time.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

other_parliamentary_business.body:
MPs on the House of Commons Environment, Food and Rural Affairs Committee have called for a ban on the export of all plastic waste from the UK by 2027 to reduce the country's contribution to global plastic waste pollution. 
Read a summary of the Committee's report on plastic waste (https://ukparliament.shorthandstories.com/the-price-of-plastic/index.html)
Report on ending the impact of plastic waste
Earlier this month, the Committee published a report on the impact of plastic waste and ways of reducing it. In their report, MPs called on the Government to restrict the amount of plastic that can be exported from the UK. They also called on the Government to step up the enforcement of existing rules to prevent criminal gangs illegally exporting and dumping UK-produced waste. 
Read the Committee's report reducing plastic waste (https://committees.parliament.uk/publications/31509/documents/176742/default/)
Read a press release about the report (https://committees.parliament.uk/committee/52/environment-food-and-rural-affairs-committee/news/174191/mps-call-for-ban-on-all-plastic-waste-exports/)
The report follows a series of evidence sessions earlier this year, where the Committee questions representatives from charities, environmental campaigners and commercial trade experts. At these sessions the Committee explored:
whether the Government’s current ambitions to reduce plastic waste were enough
how alternatives to plastic consumption can be identified and supported
how England's current plastic exports impact other countries.
Find out more about the Committee's inquiry into plastic waste (https://committees.parliament.uk/work/1391/plastic-waste/) and read oral evidence from the Committee's inquiry (https://committees.parliament.uk/work/1391/plastic-waste/publications/).
What is the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs Committee? 
The Environment, Food and Rural Affairs Committee is a cross-party group of backbench MPs that scrutinises the administration, spending and policy of the Government’s Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs. 
Find out more about the Committee (https://committees.parliament.uk/committee/365/business-energy-and-industrial-strategy-committee/)
Follow the Committee on Twitter (https://twitter.com/CommonsEFRA) for updates on its work.
 
The Environment, Food and Rural Affairs Committee is a select committee. Find out how select committees work (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o_2RDuDs44c).
Get involved in the work of the UK Parliament
Sign up to the Your UK Parliament newsletter (https://parliament.us16.list-manage.com/subscribe?u=3ad7e4c57a864f07e4db008c4&id=26d0645ea9) for the latest information on how to get involved and make a difference.
